values.description:
This adds a tutorial for the logical camera sensor. It has a small example world, explains the behavior, and has some relevant code snippets for doing stuff with the sensor.

It assumes these merged PRs have been released:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2777/logical-camera-obeys
* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2776/logical-camera-now-reports-nested-models
values.title: Logical cameraLogical Camera tutorial for gazebo 7+

summary.raw:
This adds a tutorial for the logical camera sensor. It has a small example world, explains the behavior, and has some relevant code snippets for doing stuff with the sensor.

It assumes these merged PRs have been released:

summary.html:

values.description: Users are having issues with the current tutorial for building from source as we transition to use `ign-cmake`. Since `ign-cmake` is still experimental, let's instruct users to build version 3 of `ign-math` until `ign-cmake` is really ready.
values.title: Use ign-math3 during the transition to ign-cmake

summary.raw: Users are having issues with the current tutorial for building from source as we transition to use `ign-cmake`. Since `ign-cmake` is still experimental, let's instruct users to build version 3 of `ign-math` until `ign-cmake` is really ready.
summary.html: Users are having issues with the current tutorial for building from source as we transition to use ign-cmake. Since ign-cmake is still experimental, let's instruct users to build version 3 of ign-math until ign-cmake is really ready.

values.description:
add instruction to download hokuyo model if it doesn't exist (similar to the instructions in [Attach Meshes](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials/?tut=attach_meshes) tutorial). I didn't have the model in my docker container so gzclient froze for a couple minutes while waiting for model database to finish updating


Remove sentence suggesting that `camera` model already exists in `~/.gazebo/models`. Previous tutorials do not involve a camera model so a new user would not have it in cache
values.title: Update instructions in Add Sensor tutorial

summary.raw:
add instruction to download hokuyo model if it doesn't exist (similar to the instructions in [Attach Meshes](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials/?tut=attach_meshes) tutorial). I didn't have the model in my docker container so gzclient froze for a couple minutes while waiting for model database to finish updating


Remove sentence suggesting that `camera` model already exists in `~/.gazebo/models`. Previous tutorials do not involve a camera model so a new user would not have it in cache
summary.html:
add instruction to download hokuyo model if it doesn't exist (similar to the instructions in Attach Meshes tutorial). I didn't have the model in my docker container so gzclient froze for a couple minutes while waiting for model database to finish updating

Remove sentence suggesting that camera model already exists in ~/.gazebo/models. Previous tutorials do not involve a camera model so a new user would not have it in cache

values.description:
* Mention ign-transport environment variables, since users have been having troubles with it, for example [here](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/17223). I ticketed an issue at Ignition Transport about the [tutorials website](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/issues/77/documentation-is-gone#comment-None) and for now I put a placeholder link to ign-transport3.

* Changed world example to another world different from the default

* Added more info about plugins with concrete examples and mention the change in command line flags
values.title: Updates to Components tutorial

summary.raw:
* Mention ign-transport environment variables, since users have been having troubles with it, for example [here](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/17223). I ticketed an issue at Ignition Transport about the [tutorials website](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/issues/77/documentation-is-gone#comment-None) and for now I put a placeholder link to ign-transport3.

* Changed world example to another world different from the default

* Added more info about plugins with concrete examples and mention the change in command line flags
summary.html:
• Mention ign-transport environment variables, since users have been having troubles with it, for example here. I ticketed an issue at Ignition Transport about the tutorials website and for now I put a placeholder link to ign-transport3.

  • Changed world example to another world different from the default

  • Added more info about plugins with concrete examples and mention the change in command line flags

values.description: The linked source code uses `list(APPEND ... )` while the tutorial refers to the line as `set( ... )`. It may throw off readers who aren't familiar enough with cmake to know that those expressions have the same effect.
values.title: Cosmetic change to match source code

summary.raw: The linked source code uses `list(APPEND ... )` while the tutorial refers to the line as `set( ... )`. It may throw off readers who aren't familiar enough with cmake to know that those expressions have the same effect.
summary.html: The linked source code uses list(APPEND ... ) while the tutorial refers to the line as set( ... ). It may throw off readers who aren't familiar enough with cmake to know that those expressions have the same effect.

values.description:
To better illustrate the challenges of physics parameter tuning, I increased the lateral gravity in the example from 1.0 to 3.0 m/s^2, which causes the system to diverge with 70 iterations, though it is stable with 200 iterations. I also added a profile with 500 iterations and a plot of the pitch and yaw angles of each link (which should be zero with a perfect solver) to illustrate the difference in accuracy when using more iterations. It's plain to see when the simulation is diverging, but it can be hard to discern visually the advantage of 200 versus 500 iterations.

I also fixed the coordinate labels in the text and the svg figure.
values.title: Add additional physics profile to preset_manager tutorial and make one profile unstable

summary.raw:
To better illustrate the challenges of physics parameter tuning, I increased the lateral gravity in the example from 1.0 to 3.0 m/s^2, which causes the system to diverge with 70 iterations, though it is stable with 200 iterations. I also added a profile with 500 iterations and a plot of the pitch and yaw angles of each link (which should be zero with a perfect solver) to illustrate the difference in accuracy when using more iterations. It's plain to see when the simulation is diverging, but it can be hard to discern visually the advantage of 200 versus 500 iterations.

I also fixed the coordinate labels in the text and the svg figure.
summary.html:
To better illustrate the challenges of physics parameter tuning, I increased the lateral gravity in the example from 1.0 to 3.0 m/s^2, which causes the system to diverge with 70 iterations, though it is stable with 200 iterations. I also added a profile with 500 iterations and a plot of the pitch and yaw angles of each link (which should be zero with a perfect solver) to illustrate the difference in accuracy when using more iterations. It's plain to see when the simulation is diverging, but it can be hard to discern visually the advantage of 200 versus 500 iterations.

I also fixed the coordinate labels in the text and the svg figure.

values.description:
I created a tool that automatically computes the 3D mesh geometry parameters, such as the volume, center of mass and inertia, and also cleans up the mesh by performing the duplicate vertex and face removal and removal of non manifold faces. Internally the tool simply runs meshlab (i.e. meshlabserver). 

I am using this tool for a while now, and I think it would definitely be a good asset to the Gazebo community.
values.title: Link to tool for automatic mesh geometry computation and cleanup.

summary.raw:
I created a tool that automatically computes the 3D mesh geometry parameters, such as the volume, center of mass and inertia, and also cleans up the mesh by performing the duplicate vertex and face removal and removal of non manifold faces. Internally the tool simply runs meshlab (i.e. meshlabserver). 

I am using this tool for a while now, and I think it would definitely be a good asset to the Gazebo community.
summary.html:
I created a tool that automatically computes the 3D mesh geometry parameters, such as the volume, center of mass and inertia, and also cleans up the mesh by performing the duplicate vertex and face removal and removal of non manifold faces. Internally the tool simply runs meshlab (i.e. meshlabserver).

I am using this tool for a while now, and I think it would definitely be a good asset to the Gazebo community.
